DataElement.preferredName: Specimen Prior Abnormal Excision Outcome Assessment Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type related to an abnormal outcome on a prior excisional specimen.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Specimen Prior Abnormal Excision Outcome Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to an abnormal outcome on a prior excisional specimen.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.:Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.:The result of an action.:The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates a task, process or examination that has either not been initiated or not been completed.

Concepts.definition: Indicates a task, process or examination that has either not been initiated or not been completed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lobular carcinoma in situ is characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina. The overall lobular architecture is preserved. LCIS is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral. LCIS seldom becomes invasive, however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.  --2002

Concepts.definition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Varying from the norm; not conformable to the type.

Concepts.definition: Varying from the norm; not conformable to the type.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
